text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Respiratory
Therapeutics Daily News \-- Fresh data on pharyngitis are presented in a new
report. According to news reporting from Nanjing, People's Republic of China,
by NewsRx journalists, research stated, "Relieving Sore Throat Formula (RSTF)
is a formula approved by the China Food and Drug Administration and has been
used for the treatment of pharyngitis in clinic for many years. However, the
potential pharmacological mechanism still remains unknown."

Funders for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of
China.

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing University
of Chinese Medicine: "We combined multiple methods including bioinformatics
data digging, network pharmacology analysis, and pathway analysis to predict
the potential target of RSTF. We verified our in silico prediction results
with an in vivo/vitro antibacterial effect test, mouse phagocytic index test,
proliferation, transformation, and migration of mouse spleen lymphocytes.
Alteration of NF-kB pathway was determined by Western blotting,
immunofluorescence, and PCR. The in vivo experiments demonstrated that the
RSTF could significantly relieve the symptoms of pharyngitis. A rat saliva
secretion test showed that RSTF can effectively relieve the xerostomia
symptom. A phenol red excretion test showed that RSTF has an eliminating
phlegm effect. A hot plate method and granuloma experiment proved that RSTF
also have analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects. In silico prediction
demonstrates that 70 active compounds of RSTF were filtered out through ADME
screening and 84 putative targets correlated with different diseases. Pathway
enrichment analysis showed that the candidate targets were mostly related to
the response to bacteria and immunity signalling pathways, which are known
contributors to pharyngitis."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Experimental results
confirmed that RSTF exerted therapeutic effects on pharyngitis mainly by
antibacterial effect and downregulation of NF-kB activities. It is
demonstrated both in silico and in vivo/vitro that RSTF exerted therapeutic
effects on pharyngitis mainly through an antibiotic effect and downregulation
of NF-kB signalling pathway."

For more information on this research see: Relieving Sore Throat Formula
Exerts a Therapeutic Effect on Pharyngitis through Immunoregulation and NF-kB
Pathway. _Mediators of Inflammation_ , 2020,2020. (Mediators of Inflammation -
<https://www.hindawi.com/journals/mi>). The publisher for Mediators of
Inflammation is Hindawi Limited.

A free version of this journal article is available at
<https://doi.org/10.1155/2020/2929163>.

Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by
contacting Yushi Ding, Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Pharmacology and Safety
Evaluation of Chinese Materia Medica, School of Pharmacy, Nanjing University
of Chinese Medicine, Nanjing 210023, People's Republic of China. Additional
authors for this research include Suyun Yu, Zhonghong Wei, Rui Deng, Peng
Chen, Yifan Sun, Qi Jia, Xiaoman Li, Yuanyuan Wu, Wenxing Chen, Kurt S.
Zanker, Aiyun Wang, Yin Lu.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Reports Summarize Pharyngitis Study Results from Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine (Relieving Sore Throat Formula Exerts a Therapeutic Effect on Pharyngitis through Immunoregulation and NF-kB Pathway): Pharyngeal Diseases and Conditions - Pharyngitis
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Respiratory Therapeutics Daily News -- Fresh data on pharyngitis are presented in a new report. According to news reporting from Nanjing, People’s Republic of China, by NewsRx journalists, research stated, “Relieving Sore Throat Formula (RSTF) is a formula approved by the China Food and Drug Administration and has been used for the treatment of pharyngitis in clinic for many years. However, the potential pharmacological mechanism still remains unknown.”

Funders for this research include National Natural Science Foundation of China.

The news reporters obtained a quote from the research from Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine: “We combined multiple methods including bioinformatics data digging, network pharmacology analysis, and pathway analysis to predict the potential target of RSTF. We verified our in silico prediction results with an in vivo/vitro antibacterial effect test, mouse phagocytic index test, proliferation, transformation, and migration of mouse spleen lymphocytes. Alteration of NF-kB pathway was determined by Western blotting, immunofluorescence, and PCR. The in vivo experiments demonstrated that the RSTF could significantly relieve the symptoms of pharyngitis. A rat saliva secretion test showed that RSTF can effectively relieve the xerostomia symptom. A phenol red excretion test showed that RSTF has an eliminating phlegm effect. A hot plate method and granuloma experiment proved that RSTF also have analgesic and anti-inflammatory effects. In silico prediction demonstrates that 70 active compounds of RSTF were filtered out through ADME screening and 84 putative targets correlated with different diseases. Pathway enrichment analysis showed that the candidate targets were mostly related to the response to bacteria and immunity signalling pathways, which are known contributors to pharyngitis.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Experimental results confirmed that RSTF exerted therapeutic effects on pharyngitis mainly by antibacterial effect and downregulation of NF-kB activities. It is demonstrated both in silico and in vivo/vitro that RSTF exerted therapeutic effects on pharyngitis mainly through an antibiotic effect and downregulation of NF-kB signalling pathway.”

For more information on this research see: Relieving Sore Throat Formula Exerts a Therapeutic Effect on Pharyngitis through Immunoregulation and NF-kB Pathway. Mediators of Inflammation, 2020,2020. (Mediators of Inflammation - https://www.hindawi.com/journals/mi). The publisher for Mediators of Inflammation is Hindawi Limited.

A free version of this journal article is available at https://doi.org/10.1155/2020/2929163.

Our news journalists report that more information may be obtained by contacting Yushi Ding, Jiangsu Key Laboratory for Pharmacology and Safety Evaluation of Chinese Materia Medica, School of Pharmacy, Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine, Nanjing 210023, People’s Republic of China. Additional authors for this research include Suyun Yu, Zhonghong Wei, Rui Deng, Peng Chen, Yifan Sun, Qi Jia, Xiaoman Li, Yuanyuan Wu, Wenxing Chen, Kurt S. Zanker, Aiyun Wang, Yin Lu.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
